remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I understand you experienced a fall and some changes in your level of consciousness. Can you describe what you remember about the events leading up to your fall and any symptoms you noticed right before or after it?

Well, um… I’m not sure I remember everything clearly, but I know I had a fall. I think I just sort of went down all of a sudden. My main concern right now is that it’s been really hard to breathe—like I can’t get a full breath in, especially down low in my chest. Should I be worried about that?

remedi_labels.value: can't get a full breath in
Should I be worried about that?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why experiencing short of breath would make you anxious, especially after such a serious fall. To help guide my assessment, can you tell me if your difficulty breathing started immediately after the fall, or did it develop later on during your hospital stay?

remedi_labels.value: immediately after the fall or later during hospital stay

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um… I think the shortness of breath started after the fall, not right away, but maybe a little while later. They did a chest x-ray and mentioned something about bibasilar opacities—I’m not sure what that means exactly, but it’s making me a bit anxious. Should I be worried about that?

remedi_labels.value: after the fall, not right away, but maybe a little while later
Should I be worried about that?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious about your breathing and the findings on your chest x-ray—these symptoms can feel very unsettling. When you say it’s hard to get a full breath, do you notice any associated symptoms like chest pain, cough, or fever that have developed since your fall?

remedi_labels.value: I can understand why you’d be anxious about your breathing and the findings on your chest x-ray—these symptoms can feel very unsettling.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… let me think. I haven’t really had much chest pain, but I have felt kind of feverish—like I’ve had chills and I think my temperature’s been up since the fall. And, actually, my stomach’s been paining a bit too, sort of like an abdominal pain. I’m not sure if that’s related or not. Is it normal to have all these symptoms after a fall?

remedi_labels.value: Is it normal to have all these symptoms after a fall?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for sharing those symptoms—it’s helpful for my assessment. Since you mentioned experiencing feverish with chills and abdominal pain after your fall, have you noticed any changes in your mental status, such as confusion, difficulty staying awake, or trouble speaking, since the incident?

remedi_labels.value: changes in mental status such as confusion, difficulty staying awake, or trouble speaking

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… yes, I think there have been some changes. I’ve felt kind of out of it—like my level of consciousness isn’t quite right. Sometimes it’s hard to stay awake or focus, and I haven’t really been able to speak much since the fall. I’m also worried because they mentioned something about respiratory failure, and that sounds pretty serious. Should I be really concerned about these symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: Should I be really concerned about these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with symptoms like experiencing “out of it” and concerns about respiratory failure. To help with my assessment, can you tell me if you experienced any nosebleeds (epistaxis) or bleeding from other areas after your fall?

remedi_labels.value: bleeding from other areas after fall

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, yes, actually—I did have a nosebleed, or I guess you called it epistaxis, after the fall. It was pretty heavy for a bit. And, well, I’ve noticed that my face feels kind of strange on the left side. Someone mentioned I have a left facial droop. That’s making me even more anxious, to be honest. Should I be worried about these symptoms too?

remedi_labels.value: strange feeling on left side of face
Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with new symptoms like a facial droop and changes in sensation. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any weakness or numbness in your left upper extremity since the fall, or difficulty moving that arm during examination?

Yes, actually… now that you mention it, I have noticed weakness in my left arm since the fall. It’s been really hard to move it, and sometimes it just feels numb or heavy. I’m not sure if it’s getting any better. Also, I’ve had some episodes of emesis—throwing up—and there were some bloody secretions in it, which really scared me. Is that something serious? I’m just feeling more and more anxious with all these symptoms coming up.

remedi_labels.value: numbness or heaviness in left arm

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be experiencing anxious with these symptoms, especially after experiencing weakness and numbness in your left arm along with changes in your level of consciousness. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any difficulty moving or experiencing sensation in your left leg as well, or is it mainly limited to your left upper extremity?

remedi_labels.value: weakness and numbness in left arm
difficulty moving or experiencing sensation in left leg

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… actually, it’s not just my left arm. My whole left side feels weak—I can’t really move my left leg either. It’s almost like I have left hemiplegia, I think that’s what you called it? And, I’ve had a fever over 100.5, with chills, which has me worried about infection or something more serious.

Also, I noticed that I can’t really flex or extend my neck when asked—it just won’t move the way it should. Is that something you’re concerned about? I’m feeling pretty anxious with all of these symptoms happening at once.

remedi_labels.value: concern about inability to move neck

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried with so many symptoms happening at once, especially the weakness and changes in your ability to move your left side. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your ability to feel sensation—such as numbness or tingling—on your left side during examination, or is it primarily weakness without sensory changes?

remedi_labels.value: weakness and changes in ability to move left side
changes in sensation such as numbness or tingling on left side

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, let me think… It’s mostly weakness on my left side, but I do feel some numbness and tingling too—especially in my left arm and leg. It’s kind of hard to tell exactly, since I haven’t really been able to follow commands or speak much since all this started. Sometimes I just can’t get the words out, or I don’t quite understand what’s being asked. That’s been really frustrating and honestly, it makes me pretty anxious.

Should I be worried about not being able to follow commands or speak? Does that mean something serious is going on with my brain?

remedi_labels.value: numbness and tingling in left arm and leg

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious, especially with symptoms like difficulty speaking, not being able to follow commands, and weakness with numbness on your left side—these can be very concerning. Based on your symptoms and examination findings, I’m assessing for possible neurological injury, such as a stroke or brain hemorrhage, which can affect both movement and speech. Have you experienced any changes in your vision or noticed any double vision since these symptoms began?

remedi_labels.value: not being able to follow commands
weakness with numbness on left side

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… I haven’t really noticed any double vision, but my eyesight does feel a little off—maybe a bit blurry at times, but not seeing two of symptoms. I’m not sure if that’s related or just because I’ve been so out of it.

Also, I wanted to mention, I’ve noticed some swelling in both my lower legs—like 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema, I think you called it. And there’s a big bruise with a lot of soft tissue swelling over my left knee from the fall. It’s pretty tender and looks kind of alarming.

With all these symptoms—like the weakness, the trouble speaking, and now the swelling and bruising—I’m just really anxious. Does this all fit with a stroke or brain hemorrhage? Should I be worried about long-term symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: swelling in both lower legs (1+ bilateral lower extremity edema)
bruise with soft tissue swelling over left knee

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious with all these symptoms, especially the weakness, difficulty speaking, and swelling you’ve described. Based on your symptoms—including altered level of consciousness, left-sided weakness, and findings on examination like facial droop and edema—my assessment is focused on possible neurological injury such as a stroke or intracranial hemorrhage, as well as complications from your fall. To further guide my assessment, have you experienced any new or worsening headaches since the onset of your symptoms?

Well, um… yes, I have had some headpains since all of this started. They’re not the worst pain I’ve ever felt, but they do come and go, and sometimes it’s more of a pressure than a sharp pain. I think I heard someone mention a subarachnoid hemorrhage on both sides of my brain—does that explain the headpains and why I’m feeling so “not interactive” or out of it? I just feel like I’m not myself at all, like I can’t really connect or respond the way I usually would.

I’m really anxious about what all this means. With the subarachnoid hemorrhage and everything else going on, should I be worried about my recovery or long-term symptoms? And is there anything else I should be watching out for right now?

remedi_labels.value: feeling not interactive or out of it
feeling not myself, can't connect or respond as usual
Does subarachnoid hemorrhage explain headpains and feeling out of it?
Should I be worried about recovery or long-term symptoms?
Is there anything else I should be watching out for right now?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I can understand why you’d be worried and anxious, especially with symptoms like persistent headache, experiencing “not interactive,” and the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Based on your clinical findings—including left-sided weakness, difficulty speaking, decreased level of consciousness, and imaging showing both subarachnoid and intraparenchymal hemorrhage—my assessment is that your symptoms are most likely related to significant neurological injury from bleeding in the brain after your fall. 

To further guide my assessment, have you experienced any new onset of seizures or abnormal movements since your symptoms began?

Well, um… I don’t think I’ve had any seizures that I know of—no shaking or anything like that. But honestly, with everything going on and feeling so out of it, I’m not sure I’d even notice if something like that happened unless someone told me. I did hear the team mention an intraparenchymal hemorrhage in my right parietal region, and some edema in the brain parenchyma just in front of where the hemorrhage is. That sounds pretty serious to me.

I’m really anxious about all of this. With both the subarachnoid and intraparenchymal hemorrhages, and the swelling in my brain, does that mean my symptoms—like the weakness, trouble speaking, and not being interactive—are likely to get worse? Or is there a chance for recovery? And is there anything my family should be looking out for in case symptoms change suddenly?

remedi_labels.value: intraparenchymal hemorrhage in right parietal region
Will symptoms like weakness, trouble speaking, and not being interactive get worse or is there a chance for recovery?
Is there anything my family should be looking out for in case symptoms change suddenly?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
I can understand why you’d be worried and anxious, given the seriousness of your symptoms and the findings of both subarachnoid and intraparenchymal hemorrhages with associated brain edema. These conditions can certainly explain your left-sided weakness, speech difficulties, and changes in your level of consciousness, and they do carry a risk for both worsening and long-term symptoms, though some recovery is possible depending on how your brain responds to treatment and time.

At this stage, our clinical assessment will focus on closely monitoring your neurological status for any changes—such as new weakness, worsening confusion, or decreased responsiveness—as well as preventing complications like seizures, infection, or further bleeding. Your care team will also continue supportive treatments, including careful blood pressure management, seizure prophylaxis, and monitoring for signs of increased intracranial pressure.

Given everything you’ve shared, have you or your family noticed any sudden changes in your alertness or ability to respond during examination since your last assessment?

remedi_labels.value: subarachnoid and intraparenchymal hemorrhages with associated brain edema
left-sided weakness, speech difficulties, changes in level of consciousness
risk for worsening and long-term symptoms, some recovery possible

monitoring neurological status, preventing complications (seizures, infection, further bleeding), supportive treatments (blood pressure management, seizure prophylaxis, monitoring intracranial pressure)
sudden changes in alertness or ability to respond

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… I think my family has noticed that sometimes I seem more confused or less responsive than before, especially when they try to talk to me or ask me to do something. There are times when I just can’t seem to focus or answer, and other times I’m a bit more alert. It kind of comes and goes, but overall I feel like I’m not as interactive as I used to be.

Also, I wanted to mention—I heard the team say there’s minimal frontal soft tissue swelling and some dense fluid, probably hemorrhage, within my paranasal sinuses. Does that have anything to do with my symptoms, or is it something separate from the brain hemorrhages? I’m just really anxious about all these findings and what they might mean for my recovery. Should I be worried about the swelling or the hemorrhage in my sinuses causing more symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: confusion, less responsive, difficulty focusing, decreased interactivity
minimal frontal soft tissue swelling, dense fluid (probably hemorrhage) within paranasal sinuses
relationship between sinus hemorrhage/swelling and current symptoms
concern about whether to be worried about swelling or hemorrhage in sinuses causing more symptoms
